nodes.bodyText:
Should we be ignoring "hub-core-artifacts" for both flowNames and stepNames here?
We can use a Set for flowNames and stepNames instead of an array.
No need to JSON.stringify here since name is already a string.

Once flowNames and stepNames become a Set we can use has instead of includes
Since provResults[j].associatedWith is an object, we can use String() or .toString() here.

Only this part needs to be amped. And we have a natural home for it - in prov.sjs. But let's not put it in the Provenance class (I don't think we can amp it either if we do that). Just make a new exported function in there.
To keep it flexible, make "out" (if that is really "output", let's call it "output" - abbreviations rarely buy us anything) an argument to the function. So how about - findProvenance(uri, relations).
Then, make the above amp "findProvenance.json" - no need for "amp" or "dhf" in the filename.
I think it's worth putting the invokeFunction in the amped function too, so that the client doesn't have to worry about doing that part.
To shorten this function, put all of this logic into a separate function - e.g. "getRecordMetadata".

Getting all objects in a collection is generally not a safe practice. While we don't expect there to be hundreds of flows or steps, we can't prevent that.
Instead, try the following approach:

Iterate through provResults first, building up the history array and also building arrays of flow and step names.
Take all the flow names and use those to query for only the flow objects you need.
Take all the step names and use those to query for only the steps / step definitions that you need.
Iterate back over the provResults, replacing flow/step if it doesn't exist.

Though - what's the requirement behind populating flow/step only if the flow/step still exists? If it's something for the UI, I think it would be better to add boolean properties of flowExists and stepExists. We shouldn't hide the flow/step name just because it no longer exists.

It's difficult to read this test and see that the 3 scenarios called out in the story - no prov records, 1 prov record, and 2 prov records - are being tested.
Also, I'd much rather see this tests in core DHF as opposed to HC. In HC, a single smoke test will do the trick.
So move the tests to core DHF, write the test against the EntitySearchService - call it GetRecordTest, since you're testing the getRecord endpoint - and I recommend a separate test method for each of the 3 scenarios. The steps don't matter. So for the first one, you can just ingest a record. For the second one, ingest it and map it. For the 3rd, ingest it, map it, and maybe use a custom step (or 2 custom steps instead of map). All values in each row in the history object need to be verified.

There is a getRecordHistoryTest.sjs for that covers all the scenarios. getRecord.sjs test is failing as multiple scenarios cannot be tested in ml-unit-tests due to the optic calls occurring in the same request. There appears to be a bug with Optic caching values in the same request that is being investigated.
Please move this to the prov.sjs library, as that library already has a couple functions like this, and this function isn't specific to entity search.

Let's include a comment on this function to explain why we're using "updatedTime" for something that's called "datahubCreatedOn" - i.e. we need to explain that the names in the data are incorrect, and what we're really capturing is when the record was last updated.

I'm not following the implementation here, and this is also doing potentially 3 queries within a loop. If a record has thousands of provenance records (theoretically possible), that could result in thousands of queries.
I was thinking the way to identify whether associatedWith is a flow, step, or step definition name is by the following:

Find all flow / step / step definition names, store those in 3 separate arrays
Group the prov rows by prov ID (I think you can do this in the Optic query as well, so you don't have to code it yourself)
For each prov record, convert it into a history entry. To do so, look at the values of attributedWith - if one is in flowNames, then we have a flow name. If one is in step names, we have a step name; else if one is in step definition names, we have a step name too. And you can get updatedTime / user from the first prov row, as those should be the same for each prov row.
If needed, order the history array by updatedTime

That way, we only do 3 queries, regardless of the number of prov rows.
You should be able to do a groupBy here on provID.
Though I'm not 100% sure - check with Erik about it. If groupBy doesn't work, custom code is fine.
I didn't see anywhere that this needed to be exported, I think it can be private to this library.
To make it clear what this scenario is testing, name this "recordHasMetadataButNoProvenance".
This is testing all other properties in the response from getRecord endpoint except for the history. There are 3 methods for 3 different scenarios for record history

I think JUnit is fine here, but was the problem that you had multiple scenarios in one test module? Or was there a problem with multiple test modules, each testing one scenario? In ml-unit-test, the setup.xqy module can be used for doing setup before each test module.

This was the error.
OPTIC-INVALARGS: fn.error(null, 'OPTIC-INVALARGS', errMsg+arg); -- Invalid arguments: cannot call pattern() with invalid predicates : [object Object]
I had multiple multiple scenarios in one test module
Why not use the existing ingestion / mapping steps in this flow? I ask because this project gets loaded by a lot of tests, so I'd like to only add a new artifact to it if we really need it.

         "permissions": "data-hub-common,read,data-hub-common,update"
       }
+    },

nodes.bodyText: Added new steps to verify if the step name is returned or not. Otherwise step-defintion name is returned when the existing steps are used.

nodes.bodyText:
You don't need this anymore, as flowNames = Object.keys(flows).
Also, I recommend renaming "flows" to "flowsMap". That makes it self-documenting that it's a map and not an array or sequence, which is what "flows" implies.
Recommend removing this so there's no expectation that a range index is needed.
